title: Global suicide rate map
objective: Map global variation in age standardized suicide rates
result: The legend spans roughly 5 to 35 per 100k and the map shows a wide gradient across countries. High values appear in a limited set of countries while many remain in the low to mid range
why: Choropleth maps reveal geographic disparities clearly
key_takeaway: Suicide burden is uneven with identifiable hotspots

title: Crude vs age standardized rates
objective: Compare crude and age standardized rates for ranking shifts
result: Points follow a clear positive slope between crude and age standardized rates. Several countries sit far above or below the trend which indicates that age structure can shift standardized rankings
why: Scatter plots show correlation and outliers simultaneously
key_takeaway: Age structure can change how countries rank

title: Regional distribution by sex
objective: Compare regional distributions of age standardized rates by sex
result: Male distributions are consistently higher than female across regions with visibly wider tails. Regional spreads vary with some regions showing long upper tails and higher medians
why: Violin plots expose distribution shape beyond averages
key_takeaway: Regional variability differs for men and women

title: Top depression DALYs by age
objective: Identify age groups with the highest depression DALYs burden
result: Each age panel has a distinct top 10 list and the ordering differs by age group. Older age groups show the highest values with bars reaching the upper end of the scale
why: Ranked bars make ordering and magnitude easy to compare
key_takeaway: Depression burden concentrates in older ages

title: Mental and substance deaths by cause
objective: Compare cause specific death rates across sexes on a common scale
result: Across causes the male bars are generally higher than female bars and the gap is more visible in self harm and alcohol panels. Country rankings shift by cause which implies distinct burden profiles
why: Small multiples preserve comparability across many series

title: Global age standardized rates matrix
objective: Scan cause by sex patterns in age standardized death rates
result: Non communicable diseases dominate the matrix for both sexes with the highest intensities. Mental and substance rows stay near the low end while injuries and communicable causes sit in the middle range
key_takeaway: Some causes are strongly sex skewed

title: All cause burden over time
objective: Compare all cause deaths over time across metrics and sex
result: Numbers and rates both decline from 2021 to 2023 with both sexes highest and male above female. The rate panel shows a steeper drop than the count panel
why: Faceted lines allow metric comparison without animation
key_takeaway: Counts and rates fall over time while sex gaps persist

title: Probability of death map
objective: Map probability of death for self harm in age 25+
result: Most countries are low with a few higher values led by Greenland. The range spans roughly 0.01 to 0.06
why: Maps show spatial clustering for risk probabilities
key_takeaway: Self harm risk is low overall but concentrated in a few places

title: Top 20 probability of death
objective: Rank countries by self harm probability of death for age 25+
result: Greenland is highest near 0.06 with a small group above 0.03. The top ranks are close which suggests a tight upper tier
why: Ranked bars emphasize leaders and gaps
key_takeaway: A small set of countries dominates the top tier

title: Risk factor burden composition
objective: Summarize the composition of risk factor burden
result: Substance and alcohol related blocks occupy the largest area and dwarf most other factors. Smaller categories such as tobacco and injuries contribute far less in this view
why: Treemaps show part to whole structure in limited space
key_takeaway: Burden is concentrated in a small set of factors

title: Anemia YLDs rate by sex over time
objective: Track anemia YLD rates by sex across years
result: Female rates are consistently highest across years with male lowest and both in between. Year to year changes are modest with a slight downward drift for female after 2020
why: Heatmaps reveal patterns across time and category
key_takeaway: Anemia burden changes over time and differs by sex
